to dash in pieces, literally or figuratively (especially to disperse)
to flit, i.e. vanish away (subside, escape; causatively, chase, impel, deliver)

to liquefy; figuratively, to waste (with disease), to faint (with fatigue, fear or grief)

to jump for joy, i.e. exult

play upon it; to make music, accompanied by the voice; hence to celebrate in song and music
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character

to ride (on an animal or in a vehicle); causatively, to place upon (for riding or generally), to despatch

a widow; also a desolate place

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
an abode, of God (the Tabernacle or the Temple), men (their home) or animals (their lair); hence, a retreat (asylum)
a sacred place or thing; rarely abstract, sanctity

properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry

a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
to go (causatively, bring) out, in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively, direct and proxim.

to turn away, i.e. (morally) be refractory

a parched region, i.e. the desert

to pace, i.e. step regularly; (upward) to mount; (along) to march; (down and causatively) to hurl

properly, to wave to and fro (rarely to flap up and down); figuratively, to rove, flee, or (causatively) to drive away

to be smooth (figuratively); by implication (as smooth stones were used for lots) to apportion or separate

silver (from its pale color); by implication, money
